turns.content: Project Based Learning is a learning model, what other learning models are popular in US high schoools

There are several learning models that are popular in US high schools. Some of these models include:

1. Traditional Classroom Model: This is the most common learning model in US high schools. It involves teachers delivering lectures and students taking notes and completing assignments.
2. Flipped Classroom Model: In this model, students learn the course material at home through pre-recorded lectures or other online resources. Class time is then used for discussions, group work, and hands-on activities.
3. Personalized Learning Model: This model allows students to work at their own pace and choose their own learning paths. Teachers provide individualized support and feedback to help students reach their goals.
4. Blended Learning Model: This model combines traditional classroom instruction with online learning. Students complete some coursework online and attend class for discussions and hands-on activities.
5. Mastery-Based Learning Model: In this model, students must demonstrate mastery of a concept or skill before moving on to the next level. Students progress at their own pace and receive individualized support and feedback.
6. Project-Based Learning Model: This model involves students working on real-world projects that require critical thinking, problem-solving, and collaboration. Students apply what they have learned to solve authentic problems and create tangible products.

These are just a few of the many learning models used in US high schools. Each model has its own benefits and drawbacks, and schools may choose to adopt a combination of models to meet the needs of their students.
For each of the learning models provide above, please provide positively associated keywords formatted as a python dictionary
Can you repeat the above response but formatted a a python list of dictionaries?

Sure, here are the positively associated keywords for each of the learning models mentioned above in Python list of dictionaries format:
```css
[    {'model': 'Traditional Classroom Model', 'keywords': {'lecture-based', 'structured', 'teacher-centered', 'rigorous', 'discipline'}},    {'model': 'Flipped Classroom Model', 'keywords': {'interactive', 'technology-based', 'flexible', 'student-centered', 'collaborative'}},    {'model': 'Personalized Learning Model', 'keywords': {'self-directed', 'individualized', 'autonomous', 'adaptive', 'goal-oriented'}},    {'model': 'Blended Learning Model', 'keywords': {'hybrid', 'technology-infused', 'flexible', 'customizable', 'engaging'}},    {'model': 'Mastery-Based Learning Model', 'keywords': {'competency-based', 'goal-driven', 'self-paced', 'formative assessment', 'feedback-rich'}},    {'model': 'Project-Based Learning Model', 'keywords': {'real-world', 'problem-based', 'collaborative', 'student-driven', 'innovative'}}]
```
Note that each dictionary in the list contains a `model` key with the name of the learning model, and a `keywords` key with a set of associated positive keywords.
You're welcome! Feel free to ask if you have any further questions or if there's anything else I can help you with.

[    {'model': 'Traditional Classroom Model', 'keywords': {'lecture-based', 'structured', 'teacher-centered', 'rigorous', 'discipline'}},    {'model': 'Flipped Classroom Model', 'keywords': {'interactive', 'technology-based', 'flexible', 'student-centered', 'collaborative'}},    {'model': 'Personalized Learning Model', 'keywords': {'self-directed', 'individualized', 'autonomous', 'adaptive', 'goal-oriented'}},    {'model': 'Blended Learning Model', 'keywords': {'hybrid', 'technology-infused', 'flexible', 'customizable', 'engaging'}},    {'model': 'Mastery-Based Learning Model', 'keywords': {'competency-based', 'goal-driven', 'self-paced', 'formative assessment', 'feedback-rich'}},    {'model': 'Project-Based Learning Model', 'keywords': {'real-world', 'problem-based', 'collaborative', 'student-driven', 'innovative'}},    {'model': 'Experiential Learning Model', 'keywords': {'hands-on', 'practical', 'authentic', 'reflective', 'immersive'}},    {'model': 'Cooperative Learning Model', 'keywords': {'collaborative', 'team-based', 'interdependent', 'supportive', 'social'}},    {'model': 'Gamification Learning Model', 'keywords': {'interactive', 'engaging', 'fun', 'competitive', 'rewarding'}},    {'model': 'Competency-Based Learning Model', 'keywords': {'skill-based', 'performance-focused', 'mastery-oriented', 'outcome-driven', 'feedback-rich'}},    {'model': 'Design Thinking Learning Model', 'keywords': {'creative', 'innovative', 'empathetic', 'user-centered', 'problem-solving'}}]

Note that the positive keywords listed here are not exhaustive and other sources may use different terms to describe the same learning models.
